qas.question: What are sulfonyureas commonly used for?
Nicosulfuron, triflusulfuron methyl and chlorsulfuron can be classified as what type of pesticides?
The restriction of what enzyme allows broad-spectrum herbicides to kill plants?
The amount of material used as a crop protection measure decreased from 1kg/ha in what year to its current 1%?
What has acetolactate synthase been used for commercially?
What is acetolactate synthase classified as when used on plants?
In what year was acetolactate synthase created?
How much acetolactate synthase was applied in the 1960's?
What was acetolactate synthase used for in the 1960's?

context: The following sulfonylureas have been commercialized for <a0_0><b4_0>weed control<b4_0/><a0_0/>: amidosulfuron, azimsulfuron, bensulfuron-methyl, chlorimuron-ethyl, ethoxysulfuron, flazasulfuron, flupyrsulfuron-methyl-sodium, halosulfuron-methyl, imazosulfuron, nicosulfuron, oxasulfuron, primisulfuron-methyl, pyrazosulfuron-ethyl, rimsulfuron, sulfometuron-methyl Sulfosulfuron, terbacil, bispyribac-sodium, cyclosulfamuron, and pyrithiobac-sodium. Nicosulfuron, triflusulfuron methyl, and chlorsulfuron are <a1_0><b5_0>broad-spectrum herbicides<b5_0/><a1_0/> that kill plants by inhibiting the enzyme <a2_0>acetolactate synthase<a2_0/>. <b6_0>In the <a3_0>1960s<b6_0/><a3_0/>, <b7_0>more than 1 kg/ha (0.89 lb/acre)<b7_0/> <b8_0>crop protection<b8_0/> chemical was typically applied, while sulfonylureates allow as little as 1% as much material to achieve the same effect.
